description:
Mycoplasmoides pneumoniae M129-B7 is a subspecies of the bacterium Mycoplasmoides pneumoniae, which is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia in humans. It is a small, pleomorphic, and fastidious organism that lacks a cell wall, making it resistant to many antibiotics that target cell wall synthesis.

M129-B7 is a laboratory strain of M. pneumoniae that was isolated from a patient with respiratory tract infection. It is commonly used in research due to its well-characterized genome and ability to be cultured in the laboratory. Studies have shown that M129-B7 possesses various virulence factors, such as adhesins and cytadherence-associated proteins, which allow it to adhere to and colonize the respiratory epithelium.

Genome analysis has revealed that M129-B7 has a relatively small genome size of around 816 kilobases, encoding approximately 688 protein-coding genes. The genome is characterized by a high AT-rich content and a lack of certain biosynthetic pathways, reflecting its parasitic lifestyle and dependence on host cells for various nutrients and metabolites.

Research on M129-B7 has contributed to our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying M. pneumoniae pathogenesis, host-pathogen interactions, and the development of potential therapeutic interventions against this important respiratory pathogen.
